justification: The article states that "the questionnaires administered included the Need for Cognition Scale (Cacioppo et al., 1984)", indicating this scale was used to assess the trait Need for Cognition.
It is reported that participants completed "the Pain Catastrophizing Scale (Sullivan et al., 1995)", showing this instrument measured the construct of pain catastrophizing.
The methods section lists "the Fear of Pain Questionnaire (McNeil & Rainwater, 1998)", demonstrating that fear of pain was assessed with this questionnaire.

Participants completed "the Behavioral Inhibition System and Behavioral Activation System scales (Carver & White, 1994)", identifying the BIS scale as the measure of Behavioral Inhibition System sensitivity.
The same sentence notes the use of "Behavioral Activation System scales", indicating these scales measured BAS functioning.
The article mentions administration of "the Big-Five Inventory (John, Donahue, & Kentle, 1991)", linking this inventory to measurement of the Big Five personality constructs.

It is stated that after questionnaires, "participants completed a computerized version of the Operation Span task (Unsworth et al., 2005)", indicating this task was used to gauge working memory capacity.
